Grants and Fellowships

Application Process

If you are interested in applying for a grant award, please contact Kerri Santos via email at kerri.santos / ucsf, edu at least 30 days prior to the sponsor deadline. For larger grant applications, such as proposals with subcontracts, please allow at least 60 days advance notice. For NIH Program Project, Center, Institutional Training and "U" grant proposals, please allow 4 - 6 months advance notice. The Institutional Review deadline is five whole business days prior to the day of the agency deadline. Funding Opportunities (searchable databases and agency/program-specific websites)

NIH eRA Commons User IDs/Accounts
In order to submit an application to NIH, Principal Investigators must have an NIH eRA Commons user account. To have an account activated, please send an email with your name and email address to kerri.santos / ucsf, edu In the subject line of the email, note "Request for eRA Commons Account".


Cayuse
Cayuse is a software solution that is required at UCSF for the submission of most federally funded applications via Grants.gov. Cayuse is a hosted web application that can be accessed directly from a PC or Mac desktop.

Bookmark the Cayuse Production Site to your web browser. This is the link you will use to work in Cayuse/Grants.gov.

To activate a Cayuse user account, please contact Kerri Santos via email at kerri.santos / ucsf, edu . In the subject line, write "Request for Cayuse Account". In the body of the email, please be sure to include your title and UCSF employee ID number.

NIH Biographical Sketch (aka Biosketch)
Biosketches are used to convey information about the qualifications, productivity, and the role of the personnel involved in the proposed project.  This information is available to peer reviewers as well as NIH extramural program and grants management officials. Information in the Biosketch is factored into the overall merit and technical rating for each grant application.

Unless otherwise stated in the Program Announcement, Biosketches are required for the PI(s), all Key Personnel and Other Significant Contributors (OSC). Consultants are required to include a Biosketch if they are designated by the PI(s) as Key Personnel.

Forms and instructions can be located below:

Downloadable PHS 398 instructions and the PHS 398 Biosketch Form and Sample Biosketch

Downloadable SF424 Instructions and the SF424 Biosketch Form and Sample Biosketch

NIH Public Access Policy and PubMed Central
The NIH Public Access Policy ensures that the public has access to the published results of NIH funded research.  It requires scientists to submit final peer-reviewed journal manuscripts that arise from NIH funds to the digital archive PubMed Central upon acceptance for publication.  The policy applies to any manuscript that:

  • Is peer-reviewed;
  • And, is accepted for publication in a journal on or after April 7, 2008;
  • And, arises from any direct funding from an NIH grant, fellowship, or cooperative agreement active in Fiscal Year 2008 or beyond, or;
  • Any direct funding from an NIH contract signed on or after April 7, 2008.

For more information, please see:

NIH Notice for Public Access

NIH Public Access Policy FAQ Page

PubMed Central (PMC) Homepage

NIH Manuscript System (NIHMS) Homepage

PMID: PMCID Converter

My NCBI



Responsible Conduct of Research (RCR) Resources
Principal Investigators who have been awarded grants from the National Science Foundation (NSF) are required to provide an annual certification that all undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral trainees working on their award(s) have completed training in the Responsible Conduct of Research (RCR).  More information on this NSF requirement and the RCR courses available at UCSF can be found at the following links:

UCSF Office of Sponsored Research "Responsible Conduct of Research on Federal Awards" webpage

UCSF Training Plan in Response to NSF Implementation of America COMPETES Act

Federal RCR Policies:

NIH policy on instruction in the responsible conduct of research

NSF policy on the instruction in the responsible conduct of research

RCR Training courses offered at UCSF:

  • Office of Sponsored Research's “Responsible Conduct of Research” training via the Collaborative Institutional Training Initiative
  • UCSF Training in Clinical Research Program
  • UCSF Office of Career & Professional Development
